name: matcher.TypeMatcher

methods.name: TypeMatcher
methods.example:
Implementation

const TypeMatcher(
    [@Deprecated('Provide a type argument to TypeMatcher and omit the name. '
        'This argument will be removed in the next release.')
        String name])
    : this._name =
          // ignore: deprecated_member_use
          name;

methods.name: describe
methods.desc: Builds a textual description of the matcher.
methods.example:
Implementation

Description describe(Description description) {
  var name = _name ?? _stripDynamic(T);
  return description.add("<Instance of '$name'>");
}

methods.name: having
methods.desc:
Returns a new TypeMatcher that validates the existing type as well as a specific feature of the object with the provided matcher.

Provides a human-readable description of the feature to make debugging failures easier.

/// Validates that the object is a [RangeError] with a message containing
/// the string 'details' and `start` and `end` properties that are `null`.
final _rangeMatcher = isRangeError
   .having((e) => e.message, 'message', contains('details'))
   .having((e) => e.start, 'start', isNull)
   .having((e) => e.end, 'end', isNull);
methods.example:
Implementation

TypeMatcher<T> having(
        Object feature(T source), String description, Object matcher) =>
    new HavingMatcher(this, description, feature, matcher);

methods.name: matches
methods.desc:
Does the matching of the actual vs expected values.

item is the actual value. matchState can be supplied and may be used to add details about the mismatch that are too costly to determine in describeMismatch.
methods.example:
Implementation

bool matches(Object item, Map matchState) => item is T;

desc:
A Matcher subclass that supports validating the Type of the target object.

expect(shouldBeDuration, new TypeMatcher<Duration>());

If you want to further validate attributes of the specified Type, use the having function.

void shouldThrowRangeError(int value) {
  throw new RangeError.range(value, 10, 20);
}

expect(
    () => shouldThrowRangeError(5),
    throwsA(const TypeMatcher<RangeError>()
        .having((e) => e.start, 'start', greaterThanOrEqualTo(10))
        .having((e) => e.end, 'end', lessThanOrEqualTo(20))));

Notice that you can chain multiple calls to having to verify multiple aspects of an object.

Note: All of the top-level isType matchers exposed by this package are instances of TypeMatcher, so you can use the having function without creating your own instance.

expect(
    () => shouldThrowRangeError(5),
    throwsA(isRangeError
        .having((e) => e.start, 'start', greaterThanOrEqualTo(10))
        .having((e) => e.end, 'end', lessThanOrEqualTo(20))));
